intro: Paludana, commonly known as the swamp bladderwort, is a genus of aquatic plants belonging to the family Lentibulariaceae. These plants are characterized by their small, often submerged leaves and specialized structures called bladders, which are used to trap small aquatic organisms. Paludana species are typically found in freshwater habitats such as ponds, marshes, and slow-moving streams. They are carnivorous, relying on the bladders to capture and digest prey for nutrient uptake. Their presence in an ecosystem can indicate the health of the water body due to their sensitivity to environmental changes.
